image.altText: Palestinians celebrate on top of and nearby a Israeli tank which has been set on fire near a fence

items.synopsis: A combination of old-fashioned espionage and high-tech surveillance was meant to keep Israelis safe. But when Hamas smashed through the fence, all the systems seemed to fail.

title.children: Paragliders, kidnappings and rockets: How did Hamas pull off such an audacious attack?

image.altText: Fire and smoke rise following an Israeli airstrike, in Gaza City.

items.synopsis: As the death toll from Hamas attacks on Israel and counterstrikes in Gaza climbs, Israel officially declares war and vows to attack Hamas targets.

title.children: Hundreds of bodies recovered from music festival as Israel formally declares war over Hamas attack

image.altText: A woman in a 'DISRUPT BURRUP HUB' T-shirt stands in the street with her arms raised

items.synopsis: The battle over the climate is escalating, and nowhere more than in Western Australia, where a new generation of protesters is prepared to break the law to make their point.

title.children: Tilda will remember this day for the rest of her life. It's the day she broke the law

image.altText: A two-image compilation of three women standing together and laughing, with a young woman hugging a humanoid puppet.

items.synopsis: A cruel and incurable disease took former TV personality Fiona MacDonald's voice, and her trademark quick wit and banter with it. But she's not staying silent.

title.children: 'There is no treatment, no cure': Why Fiona MacDonald is making every second count

image.altText: A close up photo of a man in a blue jacket holding a silver whistle

items.synopsis: Institutions that do the wrong thing usually do what they can to cover it up. That’s the force a whistleblower is up against, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Lost jobs, failed marriages, freedom at risk: Whistleblowers take huge risks at great personal cost

image.altText: A group of men in dark uniforms wearing helmets and holding military-style rifles stand beside an armoured vehicle on a road.

items.synopsis: Israel says it is at war as its soldiers battle Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel and launch air strikes on Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: As death toll passes 1,000, Gaza residents tell of ‘unbearable' fear and terror

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North America correspondent Carrington Clarke has been across reactions in the US. He said the message from Washington was that although the US did not currently have evidence that the attack by Hamas on Israel was directed by any other foreign agent or was in concert with them, "they are concerned that part of the motivation might have been to try to thwart the attempts, as they put it, to normalise relations between Israel and particularly with some of its Arab neighbours". Here US Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks on the issue: "It's no surprise that those opposed to the efforts to normalise relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel, and more broadly, to normalise Israel's relations with countries throughout the region and beyond, who opposes it? Hezbollah, Hamas and Iran. "So to the extent that this was designed to try and derail the efforts that were being made, that speaks volumes. "But right now, the focus is on dealing with this attack, dealing with Hamas and we'll come to the normalisation efforts — which, by the way, are very difficult when it comes to Saudi Arabia and Israel." Watch the full update from the US here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US secretary of state speaks on possible motivation for attack

children.content: North America correspondent Carrington Clarke has been across reactions in the US.

He said the message from Washington was that although the US did not currently have evidence that the attack by Hamas on Israel was directed by any other foreign agent or was in concert with them, "they are concerned that part of the motivation might have been to try to thwart the attempts, as they put it, to normalise relations between Israel and particularly with some of its Arab neighbours".
Here
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken
speaks on the issue:

"It's no surprise that those opposed to the efforts to normalise relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel, and more broadly, to normalise Israel's relations with countries throughout the region and beyond, who opposes it? Hezbollah, Hamas and Iran.
"So to the extent that this was designed to try and derail the efforts that were being made, that speaks volumes.

"But right now, the focus is on dealing with this attack, dealing with Hamas and we'll come to the normalisation efforts — which, by the way, are very difficult when it comes to Saudi Arabia and Israel."
Watch the full update from the US here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning everyone. I'm Emily Clark from ABC News International and I'll be helping to bring you updates on this story today. On the ground in Israel, the military says it has now regained control of most infiltration points along the Gaza border that were breached during the attack. Israel says it has deployed thousands of soldiers to the southern region around Gaza and was evacuating citizens from the area. Of course the country's military has a lot of questions to answer in terms of how this attack could happen. From the southern town of Ofakim that was attacked by Hamas, Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said: "The price the Gaza Strip will pay will be a very heavy one that will change reality for generations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel evacuates citizens from the south, fortifies border

children.content: Good morning everyone. I'm Emily Clark from ABC News International and I'll be helping to bring you updates on this story today.
On the ground in Israel, the military says it has now regained control of most infiltration points along the Gaza border that were breached during the attack.
Israel says it has deployed thousands of soldiers to the southern region around Gaza and was evacuating citizens from the area.
Of course the country's military has a lot of questions to answer in terms of how this attack could happen.
From the southern town of Ofakim that was attacked by Hamas, Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said: "The price the Gaza Strip will pay will be a very heavy one that will change reality for generations."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Israeli intelligence chief Efraim Halevy warned his country had no choice but to respond with full force when it comes to Hamas. Speaking to Radio National this morning, the Israeli intelligence expert and former Mossad chief said his country could not and should not stomach a situation where its citizens were being held hostage. "We've declared war and we have to realise we cannot be choosy in some of the means we have …. to reset the balance between us and them," he said. When asked whether collective punishment by cutting off water and electricity was justified, Mr Halevy said there were no rules when it came to terror. He also warned Israel had a lot of ways of making things very difficult for Hamas. "We cannot forget they (Hamas) are a terrorist group and in combating terror you cannot simply go by the book," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Israeli intelligence chief says you cannot 'go by the book' when combatting terror

children.content: Former Israeli intelligence chief
Efraim Halevy
warned his country had no choice but to respond with full force when it comes to Hamas.

Speaking to Radio National this morning, the Israeli intelligence expert and former Mossad chief said his country could not and should not stomach a situation where its citizens were being held hostage.
"We've declared war and we have to realise we cannot be choosy in some of the means we have …. to reset the balance between us and them," he said.
Former Mossad chief Efraim Halevy.
When asked whether collective punishment by cutting off water and electricity was justified, Mr Halevy said there were no rules when it came to terror.
He also warned Israel had a lot of ways of making things very difficult for Hamas.
"We cannot forget they (Hamas) are a terrorist group and in combating terror you cannot simply go by the book," he said.

image.altText: Colleen Johnstone and Phil Bayley with their son Angus using a laptop computer.

items.synopsis: Angus isn't like most other year 11 students — it takes him a lot longer to read and understand information. His school gave him extra time at his mid-year exams which really helped. The trouble is, at finals, he won't get anywhere near that — and experts say that isn't fair.

title.children: Angus needs more time in exams to help his 'brain think', but he won't get it at his finals — and advocates say that's unfair

image.altText: Artist's impression of an asteroid collision with Earth.

items.synopsis: In 2020, Oxford philosopher Toby Ord put the chances of "existential catastrophe" for our species during the next century at one in six. But does it really stack up, asks Steven Stern.
